business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of all senators, I express our deepest sympathy to the families and friends of Midshipman Megan Pelly, Petty Officer Shaun Smith, Leading Seaman Bradley Meek and Able Seaman Phillip Carroll, the service personnel who on Tuesday, 5 May lost their lives in a fire on board HMAS Westralia . I also wish to commend the service men and women who so courageously fought the fire and tended to the injured. I invite honourable senators to stand and observe a minute's silence in the memory of those who died and in sympathy with their loved ones and friends with whom we join in mourning.

speech.para: Honourable senators having stood in their places—

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Can the minister confirm that the Prime Minister stated on 4 February this year, in response to questions about Mr Chris Corrigan, `I don't have to give a running commentary on every corporate citizen in Australia.'? Is the Prime Minister's reluctance to provide a character reference for Mr Corrigan because Mr Corrigan failed to tell the truth on the AM program of 4 December 1997, when he denied any knowledge of or involvement in the Dubai training scheme; he failed to tell the truth to the Sydney Morning Herald of the same day, denying that he had provided money for Dubai; he failed to tell the truth under oath to the AIRC when he denied any financial involvement in Dubai; he failed to tell the truth to Minister Reith when the issue was first raised in the parliament by claiming that Dubai was news to him; he failed to disclose that he was the primary Australian contact for Dr Marc Faber, the financier behind the Dubai stevedores; or because he claimed that these failures were justified because it was in his commercial interest to do so and there was not an overwhelming public interest to know?

—I thought it was former Labor minister Senator Richardson who said, `Whatever it takes.' It was legitimate for Labor to lie in politics—apparently to serve its political interests, lying is okay. But then in stark contrast Senator Faulkner comes in here and suggests that Mr Corrigan lies to further his business interests and that is appalling. I would have thought that is a classic case of double standards from Senator Faulkner. I do not know whether Mr Corrigan has told the truth or not. Senator Faulkner, if he so wishes, can come in here and attack Mr Corrigan, but that is irrelevant to the issues before this government.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister outline to the Senate the government's view of these failures on Mr Corrigan's part to tell the truth to the Australian people and also to tell the truth under oath to the AIRC? Can the minister also confirm that, according to a report tabled in the South Australian parliament in 1982, Mr Corrigan and his fellow BT Australia executives `lied and invented sham transactions to cover up their role in a complex business deal.'? While you are at it, Minister, perhaps you can explain to us why Minister Reith seems so comfortable in wrapping himself in an individual like Mr Corrigan?

—I think Senator Faulkner misses the whole point. What this government is interested in is waterfront reform. What this government is interested is an efficient, internationally competitive waterfront because without that all Australians suffer and small business in particular suffers.
—Rubbish!
—Order! Senator Cook, stop shouting.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order: you have recently written to all senators talking about behaviour during question time and addressing the Senate through the chair. It is also appropriate that ministers answer questions that are directed to them through you. I directed a question through you about Mr Corrigan's lying and the attitude of the government to it. Perhaps Senator Hill might care to answer and give the government's views about this incorrigible liar.
—Schmuck.
—Is it parliamentary to call people `Schmuck'?
—I would think not. Senator Vanstone, if you would not mind withdrawing.
—I withdraw.
—Order! A question has been asked of Senator Hill. There may well be some preliminary statement he wishes to make, but I would draw his attention to the question.

—Madam President, what I am saying is that Senator Faulkner has missed the point of the government's action here. What the government is seeking is waterfront reform in order that we can be internationally competitive in that tier of business practice. In other words, in this world of globalisation, this era of globalisation, it is necessary to be competitive at all levels if you are to be an efficient exporter. This government recognises that, due to the longstanding rorts on the waterfront, which were condoned by the Australian Labor Party for so long—(Time expired)

—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. It relates to the question of jobs. Will the minister outline the reasons for the recent positive figures on unemployment, such as unemployment falling to 7.9 per cent—which happens to be the lowest level since 1990 when Labor created the recession we had to have? How is the government's responsible economic management of low interest rates, low inflation and low debt assisting families and small businesses?

—That is an important question. The reason is that this government has taken tough decisions on tough issues. In the same way that it has taken on the waterfront, it took on doing something about the gross expenditure abuse by the previous Labor government. We inherited a deficit of $10.3 billion. I would have thought that Senator Cook would have something to say about that a little later—like a personal explanation. We inherited that and we tackled it. Unlike the previous government, we did not walk away from it, and now all Australians are gaining the benefit of that.

answer.para: They are gaining the benefit through lower interest rates and low inflation which are enabling business, and in particular small business, to expand and to employ, and so we are now getting good employment figures. These are the best figures on unemployment since before the recession we had to have which was imposed on the Australian people by Prime Minister Keating and the Australian Labor Party.

What a stark contrast. The Labor Party gives you an unnecessary recession and mass unemployment. It has taken nearly nine years to recover the employment level to the situation that existed before that recession. So many Australians have suffered from unemployment as a result of the maladministration of the economy by the Australian Labor Party. So, Senator Knowles, the issue you raise is vitally important because we are now getting figures which can demonstrate to Australians that they have the opportunity for future employment.

There is no doubt that we still need to do better. Okay, we have turned it around. We have now got the best figure since 1990, but we still need to do better. And we have in place the policies that can achieve that; we have in place policies that have restrained expenditure and got interest rates down to record low levels. We are tackling the waterfront and we will achieve the competitive gains that are necessary on the waterfront. We will tackle tax reform, which is also necessary to ensure that we have an economy that can continue to pick up the unemployed that Labor unfortunately left.

There are further good signs that we can make progress in relation to unemployment. Recently, the ANZ job advertisements rose by 4.7 per cent in the year to April. In April alone, they rose by nearly one per cent. The Morgan and Banks job index survey in May showed that 17.4 per cent of firms intend to increase employment over the next three months. These are positive signs and they can give further confidence to Australians that, as a result of the policies that the Howard government has implemented, they have the best opportunity for employment that they have had for years. This is good news for all Australians and news that I would have thought that even the Labor Party would have been prepared to applaud.

talk.start.para: —No, it is misleading!

—Senator Cook interjects and says that it is not good news. I do not know what the Labor Party wants. Do they want to return to the past? Do they want to remind Australians that when Mr Beazley was employment minister we had one million Australians out of work? When the Labor leader was employment minister in this country, unemployment was over 11 per cent. We have now got it back to under eight per cent. We have made real positive gains in this regard and we have, furthermore, given hope to the unemployed—those who are still out of work. This is a real contrast and shows the benefits that can flow from sound economic management. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister: how does the government's present policy approach contrast to the previous government's approach? Is the minister aware of any alternative policies which also contrast to the government's long-term goals which should not be jeopardised if the improvements you have outlined are to continue?
—The policies of the last government, the ALP, were high taxation, high expenditure and high debt.
—Wrong!

—There is nothing to suggest that they will not go down the same path again. We heard it from the prize recruit the other day—from former Senator Kernot. She said, `Yes, there will be new taxes, but they are going to be specific purpose taxes.' Apparently that is different; that is legitimate. We are waiting, like all Australians, to actually see a detailed policy from the ALP—two years in opposition and still not one detailed policy.

answer.para: We know—due to leaked reports—that at the shadow ministry meeting on 6 April Labor said that it would be announcing a number of policy launches over the next five weeks. The five weeks have passed and there is still not one policy launch. There can be no hope for the Australian people in what is not being presented by the Labor Party. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Vanstone, representing the Attorney-General. Does the minister accept that the affidavits provided by Mr Mike Wells relating to Mr Chris Corrigan's role in the Dubai fiasco are inconsistent with the sworn evidence that Mr Corrigan gave to the Industrial Relations Commission on 9 February? Is the government concerned that Mr Corrigan's evidence appears to have been deliberately misleading in a number of respects? Will the government refer this matter to the federal Director of Public Prosecutions and, if it will not, why not?

—Senator, I think you need to understand—and you ought to already understand—that there are legal proceedings on foot in relation to some of these matters. I have no intention of canvassing publicly matters in relation to that that do not need to be canvassed, especially since the Commonwealth is party to at least one action that is now on foot. I will have a close look at your question, Senator. If there is anything in it that requires an additional remark from the Attorney I am sure he will forward you further information.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that you have declined to answer a very straightforward question, Minister. Minister, you told the ABC radio on 15 April that you would happily vote for Mr Corrigan as Australian of the Year. Minister, is this still your view?

—I did actually say that at some time earlier in the year and I added that I would vote for anybody for Australian of the Year who is conscientiously seeking to get improvements on the waterfront. That is not a portfolio matter and is not really an appropriate question. Just in case Senator Cook misunderstood: this government is about getting reform on the waterfront. We are all there behind Minister Reith. You may as well understand that, and you are not going to win in your petty little squabbling.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. I refer the minister to the additional 183,000 jobs created since August last year and the lowest unemployment rate since October 1990. Will the minister advise the Senate of the efforts being undertaken by the Howard government to provide more jobs for more Australians and to ensure that they are work ready? Will the minister also outline how these initiatives contrast with previous approaches?

—I thank Senator Synon for that very good question. The recent 7.9 per cent figure for unemployment seasonally adjusted was good news for unemployed Australians and is in stark contrast to the previous approaches of the former Labor government. In August 1993 Mr Kim Beazley, the member for Brand and the former minister for employment, said:

answer.para: There will be absolutely no chance that people will find themselves in a situation where they will get into work.
That is, under the opposition's policies. He then went on to say:
. . . unless a person is in one of our labour market programs, he or she has absolutely no chance of success . . .

That was back in August 1993 when Mr Beazley, the then minister for employment, was presiding over figures of 11.1 per cent unemployment. That is in stark contrast to 7.9 per cent, the recent figure seasonally adjusted.

talk.start.para: —What was it under Howard in 1983?

—Senator Ray, youth unemployment in Mr Beazley's time was hovering around a total figure of 34 per cent, a staggering youth unemployment figure of 34 per cent under the former Labor government. That is in stark contrast to the figures which have recently been handed down.

answer.para: This government is justifiably proud of this figure, not because it is the lowest rate in nearly eight years in relation to unemploy ment but because of the 183,000 total new jobs created since August last year. That, indeed, is a significant figure. The reason for that jobs growth is that this government has managed the economy responsibly.

Senator Synon asked: how are we doing to plan for jobs growth? How are we going to create this? We are doing it by keeping interest rates down, which will encourage business. We are keeping inflation down, which will keep the economy strong. We have introduced wide ranging industrial reforms and we have cut the red tape that small business previously had to deal with.

This government knows that it is with a strong economy that we will experience strong jobs growth. That figure for the year to April 1998—and the opposition might want to listen to this—is two per cent seasonally adjusted. We have the runs on the board. We have the jobs growth and we have the figures which prove it. Not only that, we also have the jobs network program which is going to match unemployed Australians to those job vacancies.

The jobs network, which commenced on 1 May this year, has provided for 1,400 sites for unemployed people to seek jobs. This is in stark contrast to the 296 Commonwealth Employment Service sites which previously existed. We are offering more opportunities for unemployed Australians to search for jobs. Not only that, there's more: we have a variety of jobs providers who are doing this. We have a variety of providers, some 300, and of those 246 were existing jobs providers.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The level of noise on my left is too high. Senators will cease interjecting.

—The former minister for employment, Mr Beazley, was using Working Nation as the benchmark for success. What a sorry state of affairs that was! That provided for the net cost of a job of $143,000, billions of dollars of expenditure. What did it get? 11.1 per cent, which is in stark contrast to 7.9 per cent recently announced. (Time expired)
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister further inform the Senate of other programs to address work readiness and assist unemployed people to find jobs?

—I thank Senator Synon for that valuable supplementary question. On 28 January this year this government announced further funding for the jobs pathway program to the extent of $12 million. This pathway will build a bridge between school and jobs. There is nothing factually wrong with that, as the opposition might say. The opposition does not want to have a look at what we are doing because what we are doing is succeeding.

answer.para: We are also spending $6 million on a new apprenticeships access program, and we have provided for mutual obligation, which is going to assist young people improve their skills, improve their training and make them more job ready. This will bring more young people into the employment sector.

The opposition might have talked about job programs but that is about all they did—talked and talked, more training and more training. They did not deliver on jobs. All they could come up with was 11.1 per cent unemployment under the then minister for employment, Mr Beazley, the member for Brand. That is in stark contrast to 7.9 per cent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Isn't it a fact that Minister Reith told the 7.30 Report on 27 January this year that he knew nothing of the NFF's registration of a stevedoring and training company until the 7.30 Report told him 24 hours before? Isn't it also a fact that Paul Houlihan has now revealed that Mr Reith was briefed on the Webb Dock operation on 6 January, two days before the NFF registered the three companies? Isn't it also a fact that Minister Reith learnt the thrust of the NFF plan at Webb Dock at this meeting? How do you reconcile this with the dishonest answer he gave to the Australian public through the 7.30 Report ?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I did not actually see any of those interviews, but let me make it perfectly plain: what the opposition is interested in doing here is playing around at the margin, trying to construct a conspiracy where there is not one and trying to suggest that somehow there is something un-Australian about trying to reform the waterfront by sending people offshore. There is nothing wrong with sending the likes of Senator Cook and his mates off to Moscow for regular briefings and re-education sessions, but when we try to send people off and when those who have a genuine interest in productivity improvements on the wharves want to take action to reform the process, what do they get? They get an opposition that is bound lock, stock and barrel to the MUA.

answer.para: If you want to talk about conspiracies, there is a big one going around. It is the MUA, the ALP and the trade union movement. All they are interested in is getting out there and defending compulsory unionism. Have you heard Mr Beazley say one word of criticism about compulsory unionism? Of course you have not, but he has been very busy going down to the docks and putting his hand up, hasn't he? I suppose he has to do that because he expects a bit of funding in due course. It is very important to remember that there is only one crowd in town that is interested in reforming the waterfront.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. Madam President, I direct you to the fact that Senator Alston was asked a question about the fact that Minister Reith on 27 January failed to indicate that he knew about the Webb Dock matter when he had obviously been informed about it previously. These are pretty specific questions that have been asked of him. Senator Mackay asked why Mr Reith misled the Australian people in that 7.30 Report interview. Don't you think, Madam President, we are entitled to an answer?
—I think perhaps the minister has been distracted by the interjections. Minister, I draw your attention to the question.

—Madam President, let us look at the question. It is replete with assertions and judgments about Mr Reith having clearly misled the Australian public on the 7.30 Report . I have not the slightest notion of what Mr Reith said in that interview, but I certainly do not accept the conclusion that is put forward by those who have no genuine interest in waterfront reform.

answer.para: The question also suggested that Mr Reith had obviously been informed about Webb Dock. Again, these are judgments that those on the other side want to make to distract attention from the fact that they are not interested in reforming the waterfront, not interested in being critical of those who have achieved world's worst practice on the wharves, not interested in seeing any productivity improvements brought about, and not prepared to stand up and say, as Lindsay Tanner was prepared to say out the side of his mouth to Laurie Oakes, that we cannot be caught defending the indefensible. But, no, you have been flushed out. So of course you have to get up there and do the best you can for your masters because otherwise they might withdraw your preselections.

We understand the motivation, but let us get to the issue of rorts on the waterfront and productivity improvements. Why don't you start by conceding that the wharves are a national disaster? Why don't you get out there and urge the MUA to concede that massive productivity reforms are required? We might then be able to have a genuine debate, but do not come in here making judgments about who said what on the 7.30 Report as though it has some even passing relevance to the main issues, because it has not.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was very clearly that Mr Houlihan had revealed that at a meeting on Webb Dock on 6 January Mr Reith was fully briefed with regard to this and in fact went on to say that he was not unhappy with the result. Why did Mr Reith mislead the public in the way that he did? If he had nothing to hide, why didn't he tell the truth? Who is telling the truth?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —If I had to choose between you and Mr Reith, it would be no contest. You suggest that Mr Houlihan revealed that Mr Reith had been fully briefed. I do not know what he has supposed to have been fully briefed about. Why did Mr Reith mislead the parliament? If you really want me to get you an explanation of what was said on the 7.30 Report and Mr Reith's position in relation to it, I am sure we will invite Mr Reith to respond and be as helpful as possible, but we will not for a moment let you get away from the fact that the Australian public understand where you are coming from on this.

answer.para: You only have to look at the latest Bulletin survey, but you can see it in all of the discussions and feedback we have been getting—that is, they know where you are. They know you are not interested in reforms. They know you are tied into a crowd that is simply trying to take Australia backwards. If you unravel that conspiracy and come clean on productivity reforms, we might be able to get somewhere.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. Does the minister have an estimate of the amount of revenue which has been lost to the Commonwealth because the government has decided to loan rather than auction spectrum in the changeover to digital television transmission? If so, what is that estimate? Is it the case that cabinet went against the advice of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, of Treasury, of the Department of Finance and Administration, of the Office of Asset Sales, of the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism, and of the Office of Regulation Review in framing its policy on digital transmission?
—Read out the Financial Review editorial.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I read the first sentence. I did not have a problem with that, but it went downhill badly after that I have to confess.
—Did you read the headline?
—I did read the headline, yes. I must say I was taken by surprise because I could not comprehend how a newspaper could redefine the notion of Westminster responsibility in such a manner.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I would be interested to know whether Labor worked on this basis when they were in government. The essential proposition was that if cabinet takes a decision on the advice of a minister which is to some extent contrary to the advice of the bureaucrats then presumably everyone who was a party to that decision should resign. I would like to hear of the occasions when that happened on the other side on a regular basis. This mob made decisions time and again on the basis of politics—on the basis of everything but the facts that were submitted to them. To answer Senator Bourne's question about the estimate—
—Oh!

—If you do not want me to answer it, I will not. But anyway, I will do my best. You want an estimate forgone by not simply throwing open all of the spectrum that might be available to the highest bidder. The trouble is that it is not quite as simple as that. There are a number of important policy parameters that you need to put in place.

answer.para: For example, there is more spectrum available for data casting than there is for free to air broadcasting. That part of the spectrum that is available for data casting for new entrants will be subject to free market processes and an auction which will then determine the amount that is charged to free to air players for the use of the spectrum for data casting.

In respect of the amount of spectrum that is loaned to them, not given to them, that spectrum will be capable of improvement and rationalisation at the end of the simulcast period so it would have a greater market value then than it might have now. There is no reason to assume that you are necessarily forgoing any revenue at this point in time. The fact is that you continue to derive licence fees which will reflect the additional income, if any, that is available to free to air broadcasters from digital television.

talk.start.para: —Treasury, PM&C and Finance were all wrong, were they?
—I know you have not the slightest idea on this subject, but if you want to have a sensible discussion you should ask me a question about it.
—Order! Senator Alston, you should direct your remarks through the chair.

—I apologise, Madam President, I was momentarily distracted. The fact is that if it is a criminal offence for a cabinet to take into account advice from departments and then reach its own conclusion then that is news to me. I would be very surprised if there were very many precedents for that other than on the other side of the chamber.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you did not answer the second part of the question so I will repeat it. Is it the case that cabinet did go against the advice of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of the Treasury, the Department of Finance and Administration, the Office of Asset Sales, the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism and the Office of Regulation Review in framing the policy on digital? Would it be possible to get the estimates that obviously have been made by those departments and those offices of the amount of money forgone?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —You say that estimates have obviously been made by those departments. I do not have any knowledge of each of those departments having made independent estimates of the amount of revenue forgone. I am not in the business of confirming what cabinet did in fact take into account.
—Didn't you read the coordinating comments?

—You may have read some leaked material in the newspapers and you may get quite excited about it. I come back to the point that if it is seriously being suggested that there is anything improper in a cabinet rejecting at least part of advice offered by the bureaucracy then we are fundamentally redefining the notions of cabinet responsibility. I cannot imagine how even Senator Ray—he obviously finished his run early so he has come into question time a bit earlier than usual—for a moment could suggest that that is a tenable proposition because it simply is not.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice, Senator Vanstone. Is the minister aware of threats made by the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business late last week to have the Australian Federal Police investigate principals of the firm Fynwest? Does the minister know whether such a request has been made to the Federal Police? Did such a request come through the minister or the Attorney-General? On what grounds was the request to the police made? What alleged criminal offences are being investigated?
—I am sure Senator Carr knows that there are numerous requests made for investigations to be conducted. I will take his question on notice and come back and give him further and complete advice.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I have read reports in relation to this.
—Senator Schacht, you should cease interjecting.

—I want to check those reports and check the detail of your question, Senator Carr. Let me come back to the point since you again raised the waterfront issue that Senator Cook raised. That is really what you are on about.
—Senator Vanstone, you should address the chair and not the questioner.

—Sorry, Madam President. The questions today have tended to focus on the waterfront. As I think Senator Alston indicated, if you are looking for a conspiracy you need to look no further than the MUA, the ACTU and the ALP. The problem that Labor has is that they just cannot swallow the fact that this government is determined to—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. The Minister for Justice in her own capacity and in her capacity as the Minister representing the Attorney-General was asked an extremely specific question basically about Mr Harris and Fynwest and a reference by one of her fellow ministers to the fact that these matters are going to be taken up with the AFP for investigation. He has asked specific questions about what criminal offences were involved and who referred this to the Federal Police. It was not a licence to go wandering across so she can have a bit of group therapy on the waterfront.
—I am sure the minister is aware of the question and will answer it.

—I am aware of the question and I am part way through answering it. It is important to put it in perspective. As you know, Madam President, from being in the chair, the first question to me today related to the waterfront. Then we had others in relation to the waterfront to Senator Alston and others. Now we have another question in relation to the waterfront. I think it bears putting on the record again that this government is committed to waterfront reform. We will achieve it. We will not have the Labor Party standing in the way.

answer.para: This is a very reformist government. This gives me the opportunity to back up that statement that this is a reformist government. I remind those opposite and the community at large what has been achieved by this government in the last two years. With all the reforms that we have undertaken we have the lowest home rates since Neil Armstrong walked on the moon. We have the lowest small business interest rates since—

talk.start.para: —Madam President, on a point of order: surely this part of Senator Vanstone's answer to a very specific question that was directed to her ought to be ruled out of order by you.
—I agree that the minister has strayed from the substance of the question that was asked. Senator Vanstone, if you have anything more on that, you still have time to deal with it.

—Thank you. What I was doing was putting in context the questions that have been put to me today. There is no reason why I cannot do that. I have had two questions in relation to waterfront issues, and I am just pointing out the reforms that we insist on delivering—

—Madam President, on a point of order: Senator Vanstone is now flouting the ruling you just made. You ruled in favour of a point of order I made in relation to that part of Senator Vanstone's answer being clearly out of order. She is just canvassing your ruling, in contempt of your ruling and in contempt of you as the President of the Senate, and I think you should sit her down.

—In your opinion, Senator. I ruled Senator Vanstone out of order when she strayed into talking about interest rates and matters relating to the economy. The question related to the waterfront and waterfront issues. She dealt initially with that and, while she is talking on that topic, I think she is in the range of the question. I ruled the economy out of order as straying outside the question.

—Madam President, on the point of order, and I do not want to take contest with you, the question was not on the waterfront. The question was on Fynwest and Mr Harris and putting Federal Police onto him on presumably criminal charges. It does not go to waterfront reform or anything else along those lines.
—It is not for the President to debate in detail who is who on the waterfront. I call Senator Vanstone.

—As I indicated, the two questions to me today have been in relation to the waterfront. I understand the concern by Senator Faulkner, who often turns his back when he does not like the message. I understand that they do not think that reforms such as those on the waterfront are critical to the whole economy. I understand that upsets them and I understand they do not want to know that we have the lowest home loan interest rates since Neil Armstrong walked on the moon. I equally appreciate, to conclude, that they do not want to know that we have the lowest small business rates since the Rolling Stones could not get any satisfaction in 1965. No doubt they do not want to know about it, so they will just have to realise it in their daily lives, and I will come back to this another day.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I draw the minister's attention to the press reports on 9 May which I must quote. They state, `The minister for workplace relations, Peter Reith, referred the men behind the allegations to the Australian Federal Police.' I ask you to check those reports, Minister, and I ask you this question specifically. Is it the case that this is a statement of fact and he did refer them? Or is it the case that Mr Reith was seeking to use the police and threats of investigation in an attempt to stop the Fynwest principals—Wells, Kilfoyle and Harris—from releasing the documents they did release, thus damaging Mr Reith's credibility? Isn't it the case that this government will go to almost any lengths to avoid releasing documents which would shed light on the government's role in the waterfront debacle?

—I understand Senator Carr's problem. Nobody in the ALP wants to play with him so he has to play with himself. I will get you an answer. I have told you that I will go back and look further at these matters. When I have, if there is anything to add, I will come back and give it to you. Okay?

—Madam President, on a point of order. You wrote to all senators earlier today and asked for improved parliamentary standards. Senator Vanstone, I might say, is the person who was waxing lyrical about people being turfed out of the chamber. She has already referred to members of the opposition as schmucks, which you have said is unparliamentary. We now have her latest contribution in relation to Senator Carr. Don't you think that in Senator Vanstone's case there is a bit of the pot calling the kettle black?
—I think all around the chamber there is room for improvement.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, and it refers to the government's decision during the break to cut legal aid. Is it not a fact that this will impact most seriously on the most vulnerable—that is to say, asylum seekers who have fled their own country after persecution and have arrived here lonely, frightened and with very little English? Is it fair to consider that those people should be able, without advice and support, to negotiate the complex legal processes that they need to negotiate to get residence of this country? Is it a fact that legal aid has provided thus far 75 per cent of the subsidised advice given to those asylum seekers? Will the government—(Time expired)

—I thank Senator Harradine for the question. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs has provided some information in relation to this matter and I can give you that information now. I further indicate that, if you want to give the remainder of your question to me at the end of question time, I will get you an answer as soon as I can in relation to those matters.

answer.para: The minister has been concerned for some time about the use of legal aid resources on refugee and migration applications. In these cases, the principal beneficiaries are not Australian citizens or permanent residents but people with no right to remain in Australia and who are seeking to prolong their stay. The system has also contained significant duplication, with assistance being provided through the Attorney-General's portfolio as well as through Minister Ruddock's portfolio. The Attorney-General's new guidelines complement the new immigration advice and application assistance scheme and so enable us to adopt a whole of government approach. Legal aid, of course, should be used in areas beneficial to members of the Australian community. The minister considers that discrimination and equal opportunity should continue to be defined as a priority area.

We have a first-class system for determining claims for Australia's protection, which includes a full, independent merits review by the Refugee Review Tribunal. Legal expertise is not required to make a protection claim, nor to have the claim reviewed by the tribunal. All non-citizens in immigration detention who seek to apply for a protection visa are eligible for free assistance through the immigration advice and application assistance scheme, which is managed by the immigration department. In addition, other disadvantaged applicants in the community may be eligible for assistance. The scheme provides assistance in the preparation of primary applications and applications for merits review by the tribunal. The legal aid guidelines are framed to reflect the assistance given to the protection visa applicants through the IAAAS.

The new arrangements, Senator Harradine, are consistent, we believe, with Australia's international obligations. The convention relating to the status of refugees does not require that legal aid funds be made available for making and pursuing applications seeking to engage Australia's protection obligations. Australia has an international obligation to provide legal assistance for persons wishing to challenge the legality of their detention, and that has been provided for in the guidelines.

Senator Harradine, I heard one portion of the last part of your question which related to the 75 per cent contribution. I do not have any advice on that but I will get it. I have given you the information that I have, but if you want to put more by way of supplementary or simply give me the rest of the question later, I am happy to take that too.

—Madam President, I think it is clear from the advice provided to me by Minister Ruddock that he believes the IAAAS does provide that which Senator Harradine is seeking, and it is clear to me from Senator Harradine's supplementary question that he is in disagreement with that point.

answer.para: I will take your question back to both ministers, Senator, and I will come back to you with such information as they can provide. If you want to give me the additional part of your question, as I said, I am happy to take that as well.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, my question is directed to Senator Alston representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Senator ALSTON

answer.para: Senator O'Brien interjecting—

talk.start.para: —If you think that I ought to be aware—

answer.para: What is very significant about this question, Madam President, is that the ALP seems to object to the government taking any steps to try to explore ways of reforming the waterfront. In other words, whenever you try to call in people to give you expert advice or to suggest how improvements might be brought about, all you get met with is negative carping and criticism.

Madam President, it is a matter of notoriety that this mob have been colluding with the MUA and its predecessors, the painters and dockers, and all those other wonderful people, all those friends of humanity, all those warm and caring people. I suppose you would vote for John Coombs for Australian of the Year, wouldn't you? Did you advise Mr Coombs to get out there and wear a sports coat, did you? If you think that advising John Coombs to wear a sports jacket is somehow going to persuade the Australian public that he is suddenly in favour of massive waterfront reform, then you are sadly mistaken.

The fact is that what you are objecting to is a government seeking expert advice on how we can best bring about reforms in the face of entrenched criticism. Madam President, some years ago this crowd threw about $160 million worth of taxpayers' funds at redundancy arrangements which resulted in some of those very people still being employed down on the waterfront, going through the motions, and picking up very substantial pay packets.

This government tackled the hard issues in an attempt to get around that entrenched collusion, and it did its best to obtain advice to ascertain how it can best bring about reform. That advice undoubtedly costs money when you employ people who are qualified to give it to you. I will find out for you, as far as I can, what information can be disclosed about these matters. But, at the end of the day, this was confidential advice obtained by the government.

Senator O'Brien has tried to move heaven and earth to have the details disclosed. I would have thought he had much more important policy matters to address, Madam President. But no, we are still digging around, fossicking in the dark, trying to find all these marginal aspects of a very important issue.

Never let us forget that we are the ones who want to do away with the rorts. We are the ones who want to improve productivity to generate higher exports, to produce more jobs and to make Australia more competitive. We have the runs on the board and, unless and until you wake up to the fact that there is only one party interested in these reforms, then you will go crashing to defeat at the next election.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Madam President, pursuant to standing order 74(5), I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston, for an explanation as to why answers have not been provided to questions on notice Nos 1118 and 1129 which I asked on 30 March and 7 April 1998 respectively.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I acknowledge that Senator O'Brien contacted my office this morning to inquire as to progress. Accordingly, we made contact with the minister's office and relayed the concerns. As I understand it, every endeavour will be made to comply with that request as soon as possible.
—I move:

The government claims it has nothing to hide in relation to its involvement in the whole waterfront fiasco and specifically in the training of industrial mercenaries in Dubai, but to date everything has been hidden. This whole bizarre affair still has some considerable way to go. And all the details of the role the government played in the illegal sacking of an entire work force of 2,000 Australians who support 2,000 Australian families are yet to be revealed. But they will be.

It is often the case that questions on notice are not answered within the required 30 days, and there are often good reasons for such delays, but these questions go to a very important issue, as I have said. They go to an issue that has commanded more space in the newspapers and more time on radio and television than just about any other issue in recent times. They go to an issue that has entangled not only the minister for workplace relations but the minister for foreign affairs, the Minister for Defence, the former minister for transport and now the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) himself. SENATOR THE HON. CHRISTOPHER ELLISON
Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training
Senator for Western Australia
Senator Stott Despoja
Deputy Leader, Australian Democrats
212 Grenfell Street
ADELAIDE SA 5000

talk.start.para: —Once again in question time and in this debate, Senator Faulkner has missed the point of this whole issue of what waterfront reform is all about. He chooses to try to character assassinate the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Peter Reith, and a number of other people rather than address the issues. A report on waterfront reform was released by the Productivity Commission 14 or 15 days ago. It would be interesting to know how many on the other side bothered to read and study it and recognise the necessity to do something. We have two situations here, with the Labor side defending the indefensible—it is absolutely impossible to defend what has been going on—and the government side trying to do something by getting some productivity improvement into our waterfront and improving our ability to compete.

speech.para: I want to run through a few of the issues that were raised in that report because they are very important. These are the things that the public need to know about. They need to know why it is necessary to reform our waterfront. I will touch briefly on some of the matters raised in respect of the Productivity Commission reports. The first point is that it:
Fully supports the Government's position that substandard waterfront performance is hurting Australia and reform is needed.
The following comment is made in regard to the second report:
Shows how labour arrangements are retarding container stevedoring performance.
The document went on to list a number of things and I will touch briefly on some of them. Under the heading `Container stevedoring' it listed the following:
a. charges higher than overseas
b. shiploading & unloading slower
c. poor reliability (a large proportion of ships are delayed in Australian ports)
d. increased costs to users
e. significant scope for improvement.
With regard to MUA working arrangements and work practices, the following items are listed:
a. complex, inflexible system
b. retards productivity
c. increases costs
d. reduces reliability
e. entrenches `overtime culture'
f. the `pick' or order of engagement is a key problem
g. high shift premiums and overtime.

These are some of the issues. When are Labor Party senators going to get dinkum about this issue and do something about it? They should support a coalition government that is trying to do something about it. They should say to the people that they support, `You've got to lift your game; you've got to lift your performance. It is in the interests of Australia that you do so.'

An example of an industry that is having some difficulties right now is the wool industry. Just moderate reform on the waterfront would be worth at least 6c per kilo to every woolgrower in this country. The benefit of that to the community would be absolutely enormous. They are the plus dollars; they are the dollars that get spent; they are above and beyond the cost of production. Yet this lot on the other side continually hide behind their old charade. As Senator Alston said in answer to a question today, the conspiracy is really between the Labor Party, the ACTU and the MUA. Would Senator Collins give us a line? Would he give us a word? Not a word. He said, `That is government property. We have this right as a government.' Let us touch on a couple of other things. All we have asked for on the waterfront is a lift in container rates from 18 to 25. Yet we find that New Zealand is doing better than that. We find that Thailand, using the same equipment, has a rate of 30 an hour. Fremantle has only 18.9; Brisbane, 16.8; Sydney, 18.4; Melbourne, 18.8; and Adelaide, 21.4. We should look, for example, at double-header time—that is, back-to-back shifts on Saturday, when people working on the waterfront earn $630 as a result of poor unexplainable work practices which exist in that indus try. That is what this debate is about, and that is what has to be addressed. The Australian public know that that has to be addressed in terms of fixing up the problem. (Time expired)

I will quote some words of certain people. It might be interesting for people to decide who might have actually said this and about whom. One quote is:

speech.para: My message to them is that they will cop every instrument of punishment and retribution and reaction that the operators bring against them. It is a different game this time boys; it's war. They are exceptionally greedy.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion to take note of the answers given by Senator Alston and to say, `What a differ ence five weeks make.' That is what they were congratulating themselves on in the other chamber on 8 April. They were slapping each other on the back and saying, `We've achieved a major victory. Senator Hill interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I also rise to take note of the answers given by Senator Alston. We have heard in this place today questions from Senator Quirke, Senator Faulkner and Senator O'Brien about who knew what, when they knew it, why they knew it and how they knew it. But the real question surely is: who is interested in waterfront reform? Let us have a look at the evidence. Interestingly enough, John Coombs, the National Secretary of the MUA, claims to be interested in waterfront reform. On the Four Corners program on 9 March, just a few weeks ago, he said:

speech.para: I accept that productivity . . . can always be improved, and that's what I'm about . . . trying to improve productivity . . .

. . . I endorse the activities of the Maritime Union of Australia . . . on the whole the union movement has handled this quite well and I think they ought to go on handling it that way—quite well.

So the Leader of the Opposition, contrary to the views expressed at the same time by the union president and the union secretary, does not favour waterfront reform. He pays very poor lip-service to waterfront reform.

The only time Mr Beazley had supported waterfront reform was under the WIRA process when $420 million of taxpayers' money went the way of the waterside workers. A better question for the opposition to have asked today would have been: how many of the MUA are still working on the waterfront after they took the WIRA package comprising $420 million of taxpayers' money?

Perhaps another better question that Senator Carr might consider asking tomorrow is: what did Neville Wran deliver in that report that we never saw—that, as Senator Campbell said, was never laid on the table. A better question for Senator George Campbell to ask tomorrow might be: what was delivered in Neville Wran's package of consultancies to the government of the day, the previous government, for the $304,000 that he was paid? If it was annualised, it would even make a wharfie embarrassed because it was $760,000 for a two-day a week, part-time job. It sounds a bit like the sort of productivity we have come to accept on the waterfront. But not any more.

During the past week, I had the pleasure of attending a small business meeting with the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, Mr Peter Reith. I sat next to a small businessman who previously had been a Vietnam veteran. He told me that he had been in Vietnam as a 19-year-old and he had spent two Christmases in Vietnam. The first Christmas he got no letters from home because the wharfies would not load the mail bags, and the second Christmas he got no Australian beer from home because the wharfies would not load the beer.

That is a long time ago, but that is why this community, three to one, supports waterfront reform. We will deliver it; we will go the extra mile; we will make the hard yards; and we will deliver the ports of this country an efficient, effective union and non-union work force.

talk.start.para: —I also support the motion to take note of the answer given to the question asked by Senator Mackay. At the outset it seems that two matters need to be identified. Firstly, this whole waterfront dispute is now not about reform, productivity, growth, improvement, more jobs, better jobs, or sound and sensible ongoing permanent reform. The entire trade union movement, individual unions and whole sectors of industry have been engaged in that process since at least the early 1980s. For the last 15 years, all of the former union officials on this side of the chamber have been actively engaged in that reform process.

speech.para: Repeatedly, the ALP through the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has said that this party in government will recommit to reform and achieve that end. Our record on that issue is sound. It is proud and it has stood the test of time. So if this issue is not about waterfront reform, one asks the obvious question: what is it about? It is about one thing only—bashing and destroying the MUA—and that process is to be achieved by illegality, deceit, corporate manipulation, surprise, and the engagement, hiring and training of de facto mercenaries.

Today in Australia the lesson for children at school, the lesson for the business community and the lesson for the entire Australian community is that the end justifies the means. The litany of illegal and improper activity by this government, Minister Reith and a range of private interests is now emerging inch by inch, and other questions in today's question time outlined the scope of those lies and that deceit.

There were multiple instances of Mr Corrigan lying on 4 December when he denied any knowledge of involvement in the Dubai training scheme. Mr Corrigan lied to the Sydney Morning Herald on the same day, denying that he had provided money for the Dubai training scheme. Mr Corrigan lied under oath to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission when he denied any financial involvement in the Dubai training scheme. He lied to his friend and ally Minister Reith when the issue was first raised in the parliament by claiming that the Dubai scheme was news to him. Most interestingly, he claimed that those particular lies were justified because it was in his commercial interest to do so and there was an overwhelming public interest to know.

Mr Howard condoned asset stripping as a tactic to avoid a company's normal contractual obligations to redundant workers. The same Mr Howard was apparently happy to condemn asset stripping as a device for companies to avoid tax liabilities back in 1982-83. Apparently, those unacceptable practices 15 years ago are okay when they involve the illegal sacking of workers in 1998. We have a tissue of lies from Mr Corrigan and an about-face by Mr Howard.

We come now to the arch-protagonist, the leader in this whole dispute, Mr Reith. We know that Paul Houlihan told Mr Reith of the Webb Dock operation on 6 January, two days before the NFF registered the three companies. We know that 21 days later Minister Reith told the 7.30 Report, on 27 January, that he knew nothing of the NFF registration of the same stevedoring and training company. Why do we continually have these lies from Mr Reith and Mr Corrigan and apparent about-faces by Mr Howard? The answer is clear: the end always justifies the means—we bash the MUA and we destroy the union. That is what this whole dispute is and will be about.

Similarly, with respect to Dr Stephen Webster and his mates well-known Liberal Party operators Jonathan Gaul and Mark Textor, there was no tender process for government consultancies involving the huge sum of $95,000. Dr Webster was working directly to Minister Sharp and Minister Reith as a consultant, but the consultancy fees were paid directly by the department. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired. The question is that the motion moved by Senator Faulkner be agreed to.

—On behalf of the President, I present a statement on the declaration of interests by senators. Copies of the statement have been circulated in the chamber and, with the concurrence of the Senate, I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.

In the Senate on 23 March 1998, I referred to the question whether declarations of interests made in relation to a bill should be required to be repeated at subsequent subsidiary stages of the consideration of the bill. I indicated that I would ask the Committee of Senators' Interests to consider the matter. That committee has now indicated that it has agreed that a change should be made to the Senate's requirements so that declarations of interests in relation to a bill can apply in relation to all stages of a bill except where an amendment to a bill raises some issue requiring a further declaration.
The Senate may therefore wish to consider a change to the relevant order of the Senate.
The change could be achieved by adding the following subparagraph to paragraph 5 of the Senate's order of 17 March 1994:
(2) For the purposes of subparagraph (1), in proceedings on a bill a declaration of a relevant interest shall be made:
(a) when a senator first speaks in debate on any stage of consideration of the bill; and
(b) when a senator first votes in a division at any stage of the consideration of the bill; and
(c) when a senator speaks or votes in a division on an amendment to the bill which raises an issue not included in an earlier declaration of interest during proceedings on the bill.

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the following subparagraph be added to paragraph 5 of the Senate's order of 17 March 1994 relating to the registration and declaration of senators' interests:
(2) For the purposes of subparagraph (1), in proceedings on a bill a declaration of a relevant interest shall be made:
(a) when a senator first speaks in debate on any stage of consideration of the bill; and
(b) when a senator first votes in a division at any stage of the consideration of the bill; and
(c) when a senator speaks or votes in a division on an amendment to the bill which raises an issue not included in an earlier declaration of interest during proceedings on the bill.

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to make a short statement on that notice of motion.
—Is leave granted?
—What is it about?
—I will be very brief—two minutes.
—You can speak on it tomorrow.
—I might not be able to speak on it tomorrow, that is the problem.
—It might be quicker to do it today.

—This is a recommendation from the President regarding the declaration of senators' interests, a matter in which, as the Senate will be aware, I have had a close and abiding interest. It is a sensible set of recommendations. It means that, instead of having to repeatedly get up and declare interests, senators will be required to do so only once during the course of a bill and once while voting on a bill, unless an amendment is introduced, in which case they will need to decide whether to declare an interest when a new matter is raised.

speech.para: I will be supporting the motion if it is put forward as the President has indicated because I think it will lead to a smoother application of the extraordinarily important Senate standing order that senators must get up and declare an interest when they have a proprietary interest or they have the potential to gain from their contribution to a debate or from voting in this place.

talk.start.para: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 9 April 1998 of former Senator David Bernard Vigor, a senator for the state of South Australia from 1984 to 1987.
—by leave—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Thursday 9 April 1998, of David Bernard Vigor, a senator for the State of South Australia from 1984 to 1987, places on record its appreciation of his public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

David Vigor was born in France on 24 June 1939. He moved to Australia with his family when he was 12. David was educated at Adelaide Boys High School and the Universi ty of Adelaide. He was also one of the first research students at Monash University. Before entering federal politics, David had been a university lecturer, a pioneer in the area of computer science and a farmer. While lecturing at the University of Glasgow, he developed the first computer data-based expert system used for medical diagnosis by the Western Regional Hospital Board in Scotland.

In 1971, David and his wife Susan returned to Australia and David joined the South Australian Institute of Technology as head of the school of data processing and director of the computer centre. Together, they bought a mixed cereal, dairy, poultry and sheep farm in the Barossa Valley in South Australia to accommodate their growing family, as well as to expand their business challenges. Today, their farm is a base for an executive training facility and computer consultancy which developed and markets an innovative medical system to help in-patient care and management of medical practices.

David was a founding member of the Australian Democrats and was elected to the Senate in 1984. He was national Vice-President of the Australian Democrats from 1983 to 1984 and a member of the Senate Legislative and General Purpose Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment. In his maiden speech he stated his belief that you can `change the world in which we all live'. These were words to live by for David Vigor.

He assumed his Senate duties with enthusiasm. He introduced private members' bills on varying subjects and was tenacious in his questioning in Senate estimates sessions. He was also a staunch supporter of proportional representation and self-government in the ACT. He showed endless support for individuals and struggles with the legal system and bureaucracy. For example, he highlighted the problems with the Australia Card.

He left the Senate in 1987 and went on to become a founding member and at the time of his death was Secretary of the Association of Former Members of the Parliament of Australia. After politics David returned to computer consultancy and software develop ment. The day before his death he attended the opening of a dental research unit at the University of Adelaide which featured software developed by his company.
Madam President, on behalf of the government, I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the opposition, I wish to associate the opposition with this condolence motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Hill) on the death of David Vigor, a former Democrat senator from the state of South Australia. Labor senators expressed our sorrow at David Vigor's sudden death last month and we, too, offer our deepest sympathy to his family.

speech.para: As Senator Hill has indicated, David Vigor was elected to parliament until 1984, but he was unsuccessful in retaining his Senate seat in the 1987 double dissolution. So David Vigor was a senator for only a very short period of time, but I am assured by many people in the chamber who served with him that he certainly made his presence felt during that period.

He was a man of strong principle and conviction. He fought hard and, I am assured, long for the issues that he believed in. He did advocate strongly proportional representation and self-government in Canberra. That was part of what was a strong personal commitment to fair elections and responsible government. He was also very active on consumer issues as well as fighting to ensure funding for all levels of sport Australia wide. I understand from colleagues how vigorous and thorough his questioning was at times at Senate estimates committee hearings, and many senators in this chamber have shared those experiences with him.

There was another one of David Vigor's achievements which perhaps he is not recognised as widely for, which is the role that he played in stopping smoking on Australian aircraft. That perhaps was an achievement not welcomed by all Australians but I must say, as a frequent traveller and one who does not smoke, it was certainly one that I would welcome and I am sure many other fellow travellers do.
Let me say to David Vigor's family, on behalf of all opposition senators, we offer to his family our most sincere regret at his death and our condolences to his family and friends.

talk.start.para: —I rise also to speak on the unexpected passing of former Senator David Vigor. Twenty-three Democrat senators have served in this chamber over the past 21 years, but this is the first time that a condolence motion has been necessary for a Democrat. Therefore, it is fitting that I, as current leader of the party, should make these comments.

speech.para: There have been obituaries published which detail David's life prior to politics and told by people in a better position than I who only came to know David at the time that I became involved in the South Australian division actively in 1986. So I would like to take up the tale at the time that I met him.

Yes, I knew him through his and my involvement in the party in South Australia. In those early days of our acquaintance he struck me for the very qualities that no doubt he is best remembered for by those who served in this place with him. He was enthusiastic, indeed incredibly enthusiastic, about all the issues that he was involved in. He was capable of great passion. He was a man of commitment and an avid technophile.

He was a founder member of the Democrats and gave long service both on our state executive and also at national executive level. He served as deputy national president, as has already been mentioned, in 1983-84. Later in 1984 David Vigor was elected to the Senate, giving the Democrats a second South Australian Senate seat, a seat today held by Senator Stott Despoja. This was a milestone for our party in South Australia and one of which David could be rightly proud. When elected, David was one of only five non-British European born MPs in the Australian parliament. He and his father in particular were incredibly proud of their cultural heritage.

There are many in his class of `84 who are still with us—amongst them Senators Vanstone, Cooney, Knowles and McKiernan, who probably all have a personal story or two about David Vigor. Unlike many of these honourable senators, the then Senator Vigor did not have any period on the back bench. On his first day in the Senate chamber in the Old Parliament House he held the portfolios for us of trade, transport, science, communications, local government and administrative services and territories. He attacked all of them with gusto. I am told by some who were around at the time that whatever David Vigor did as a senator he did with gusto, whether it was legislative debates, committee work—and I have quite a few stories about his work in estimates committees—or indeed placing questions on notice. I suspect that, if one goes back through the Hansard, one would see that he held close to the record for the largest volume of questions ever placed on notice in any 12-month period.

In the 1984 campaign which saw David elected, our party's slogan was `You can change the world' and, in many ways, this describes David's attitude to politics. He believed in it, he tried to achieve it and indeed he lived it. He was a central player in the move to self-government in the ACT and a tireless advocate for the science community within public life. He also took a strong interest in improved electoral and parliamentary procedures. One of his many ideas, a 1987 amendment to require senators to declare any interest in the outcome of a vote, is well known to current senators. Indeed, it is what we dealt with immediately prior to this condolence motion. While it took until 1994 to be accepted by this chamber—and, unfortunately, by that time David was no longer here—it is one of his many initiatives.

Outside the parliament, David Vigor was an enthusiastic contributor to the community—a founding member of the Australian Democrats, active in the campaign for proportional representation, a founding member of community television through ACE Television in Adelaide, and a founding member of the Association of Former Members of the Parliament of Australia. At the time of his death, he was secretary of the association.

Before I conclude my remarks, I cannot fail to mention the fact that, eventually, David Vigor and I found ourselves on the opposite sides of an inter-party disagreement within South Australia, one which saw David Vigor unsuccessfully contest the 1987 election as a candidate for another party. This party was a very short-lived one. However, many members of the party in South Australia still hold great affection for him and view the internal drama of 1987 in the context of a life of active enjoyment with and contributions to the community in which he lived.

David can rightly be described as having lived an extraordinary life. I offer my sincere sympathies to his wife, Susan, to his children and to his grandchildren. It must be for them a time of great sadness. My final words which best describe the motivation behind his political involvement have been provided by David Vigor himself. Knowledge is power, power to change the world we live in for the better if we care. No-one who ever knew him in the Australian Democrats or elsewhere will ever doubt that David Vigor cared.

talk.start.para: —I join with my colleagues in speaking to the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill in respect of former Senator David Vigor who came here in 1984, and I express my sympathy to his family at his death. He could only have been 57 or 58 years old, which is too early to go. Not only did he have a parliamentary career but I believe he was very successful in the computer industry. One thing you could say about David Vigor was that he was enthusiastic. I believe that he was the most vigorous debater this parliament has ever seen. In fact, at one stage we took a rough calculation and we believe that one senator, David Vigor, was using one-third of the Senate's time. He almost had former Senator Walsh driven to distraction at the estimates committees. He gained some fame in his one term of office.

speech.para: He was a pleasant person, a person who really got excited about any issue that he became involved in. He became involved in very many issues in his one term of parliament. He is one of those characters who will always stick in your mind. Many people come and go, but David Vigor was different. He will be remembered by all of us who were here in 1984. I once again express my sympathy to his family and his wife and say to them that we are thinking of them in this hard time.

talk.start.para: —I support the condolence motion moved by Senator Hill on the passing of David Bernard Vigor. I do so as I regarded his friendship as being very important. Vigor by name and vigour by nature, although they are spelt slightly differently. His name was spelt V-i-g-o-r, but in the v-i-g-o-u-r category he left other people for dead. His enthusiasm for this place and for this particular chamber was extraordinary, probably a little overemphasised. He had a little bit of an inflated view about the power of the parliament as distinct from the power exercised by others outside of this parliament. I am stating this as a matter of fact, not as a desirable proposition.

speech.para: He of course placed numerous questions on notice and his questioning of ministers in this chamber was direct and well researched. He had a number of private members' bills prepared and tabled in this place. I would like to associate myself with my parliamentary colleagues in offering condolences to David's wife, Sue, to his family and extended family.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take the opportunity of this condolence motion to express my sympathy to the family of the late David Vigor. He was a hardworking senator, highly motivated, and had a huge capacity for hard work. His office in Parliament House was a mass of files, with a major shelving arrangement bisecting his room.

speech.para: There are not many technocrats in this place. However, it is a lot richer for people like David Vigor and even Bruce Childs, who was another technocrat. Such people bring to this place a specialisation that makes people sit up and take notice when they talk.

Although he was here for only one term, David Vigor put much energy and enthusiasm into his work and placed many issues on the Senate agenda. It would take others 10 years to achieve such a record. His questioning at estimates brought profound respect—the manner in which he researched his questions, the number of questions and the vast range of issues that he covered simply amazed many of his admirers as well as his detractors. I believe he made a significant contribution to this place. However, I do not think he realised all his expectations as a result of coming to the Senate, but I think few of us do. Certainly while David was here he enriched this place. He was one of those senators who people will long remember.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

Parliament House

Dear Minister

I refer to the Veteran's Vocational Rehabilitation Scheme, being Instrument No 5 of 1997, made under subsection 115B(1) of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 , which seeks to assist specified classes of veterans to find employment and to continue in employment.

Clause 1.3.1 defines a service provider as a person or organisation with which the Commission or the Department has entered into an arrangement to provide services. It would appear from the tenor of the Scheme as a whole that such service providers may well be commercial organisations. However, there is no avenue provided in the terms of the Scheme whereby a person or organisation, which is dissatisfied with the decision to reject its application to be a service provider, may seek a review of that decision.

Clauses 1.4.1 to 1.4.3 permit the Secretary to require a veteran to be examined or assessed, or both, by a service provider, and for that service provider to report to the Secretary, who in turn reports to the Commission. However, there is no provision in the Scheme requiring the service provider to maintain confidentiality of the information it acquires in that process. Since the service providers may be private individuals or companies, it does not appear that they would come within the restrictions of the Privacy Act 1988 , with the result that any requirement of confidentiality would have to be included in this Scheme.

Paragraph 1.5.2(b) requires the service provider or the Secretary (if they have prepared a rehabilitation plan) to agree with the veteran on its details. The Committee suggests that this provision could not be enforced as the law cannot force parties to come to an agreement.

Clause 3.2.3 provides that an approved scheme should not normally include particular elements. If a scheme were not to be approved because it contained some such element, it would appear to be impossible for a veteran to succeed in a review of that decision. The Committee notes that there are no criteria by which the reviewing body might determine whether the case before it was normal or not. Even if it were found to be abnormal, there is no indication whether that circumstance would be enough to permit the reviewing body to include the relevant element.

Clause 4.5.2 gives to the Secretary a discretion to determine whether or not a grant has been applied for a proper purpose. However, Chapter 5, which deals with rights of review, applies only to the review of decisions of the Commission, and hence does not apply to the decision of the Secretary under this clause. There does not appear to be any provision in the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 which allows for review of any decisions of the Secretary. The Explanatory Statement would also appear to be misleading as it does not qualify that reference to rights of review to decisions made under the Scheme are those of the Commission only.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
The Hon Bruce Scott MP
Minister for Veterans' Affairs
